content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												There is a lot to say about this game...Positive:Amazing world is a good game to kill time and unleash your inner childhood with some Nickelodeon cartoon style mixed in and cute designs like Webkins. Now with new animals : Fox,elephant, dog, etc, it's fun to run around as a fat chubby animal with no physics what so ever in the game so your pleased to go through walls and floors once in awhile. In-game coin is very easy to gain just with easy mini-games such as collecting this or puzzles or match up games as quest and exp gain. Negative:As some people have already said in some reviews, the game is like Club Penguin's money system. The max level for a normal player is at 10, although you can still continue the game and its story line but you are unable to access emotions/dances and moves, clothes or items above level 10. Even if you bought a membership, its going to cost 30 bucks just to last so long before you have to keep paying again. You can talk, but some words are censored because of it being targeted at lower age audience. Some shop items are also real money turned into golden game-coins which if you want a specific item you have to pay to get it, so for example there is a Galaxy shirt in the shop that is animated and moves while in-game free money for little nubs like me to use to buy stuff, is plain and does not have animation or effects like real money buyers would. Again, there is only so much a person can buy if they can not afford membership and a lot of it is not a wide range of choosing other than plain outfits.If paying to play is not an issue for you:If you pay for a membership, your allowed access to reach the max level 50, unlocking all the dances,moves,emotions etc and the whole shop to your full gain to buy stuff even new characters(this is with real money though not in-game money) and some special effects. Although this will not help you in any quests, you will look Fabulous in the whole community. Recommend? It is a good playful game, but for somebody like me were money is an issue and something I cant just blow on, I wouldn't recommend it to them. But if money is not an issue then try it out if your into this style of free-world gameplay and enjoy yourself :3!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												It's hard for me to de-recommend this game, because it's not -bad-, I just think it is a bad idea.Amazing World is clearly aimed at children, and for what it is, I think it's excellent work, but is this really how anybody wants their child spending their time?It's a very happy, positive, friendly game with charming artwork and simple controls. Frankly, I think Ganz has done splendid work with this, in terms of design and production, but I just can't get over it being an MMO designed for CHILDREN. As in little children. I'm not against games being designed for children if they are educational, or in some way productive, but I didn't encounter anything I could describe as educational while I was in the game. In that way, I can't see any good cause for this game.The game encourages you to help others by rewarding you for doing various chores and solving puzzles. I guess you could say this is teaching good social behavior and work ethic, but real life is not like that at all. In reality, you spend a century or so working yourself to your grave and get nothing out of it. I am not a parent, though if I were, I would hardly stand for my child being (brainwashed?) made to think that doing good things means getting good rewards. Rather they should learn about the real world and be prepaired for what to expect from it. So in that way, I think this game is probably even harmful.I suppose there may be some small audience this game is just right for- if you have a small child that is handicapped in some way that prevents them from playing or studying and they need some nice way to pass their time between surgeries or treatments or just in general, then perhaps this could be a good escape for that child to do something entertaining that isn't full of distasteful nonsense like guns and explosions and zombies. Outside of that, I think any child is better off doing something that builds real skills like drawing or playing with building blocks.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												First i want to say, that the term "Free to play" needs to be redefined.You can play for free until you become level 10, (You can still play, but not advance on your main xp) then you have to subscribe to a monthly membership.There are two kinds of progression, the XP and SP. you get SP (skill points) for certian missions, such as cooking, science, depending on which chacters you speak to. These missions and skills can be played and leveled foreverSome of the characters require you to be a certain level to speak with them (XP lvl), and that's the one that will only get to level 10 for free playersIt's a cute MMO, or just MO, it is not that massive. You run around questing, doing different mini games, chat with others, decorate you house, or whatever you feel like.decorations and outfits can be earned doing quest, or be bought using either in-game cash or eshop coins. I cannot comment on the story or what happens after a certain point in the game since i did not pay, but I enjoyed it, and would recommend it though its unfortunate free players don't get more than a small demo.

												Amazing World is a much different kind of mmo instead of fighting action packed you get cute funny little animals. It focuses on taking care of your very own garden and help the the town from being took over by the Queen Vexa. Now your more of just running up to the nix and scaring em off but theres a lot more to the game then all that. Theirs cute and fun minigames that seem to be different every time to from a mario like side scroller to riding a cute little car or even fixing puzzles.  The down side of it is once you hit level 10 you hit the end of the road for free to play. Now $4 a month seems reasonable to me for this funny little game but if you don't pay no more game for you! Its would be good for any age as long as they like cute.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												Well to begin with the game is VERY cute. It is very easy to pick up and play and is child-friendly. There are definitely some bugs, but this is a new game so there is definitely hope of them getting fixed too. The first character I made I lost because when it got to the registration part it didn't work. I could not put in a username at all. So I restarted the game, made a new character, and then it worked. I was enjoying it until I kept getting very laggy as I phased in and out during the beginning quests, after you get to the town. Then I noticed a lot of adverts for membership. I also noticed some microtransactions. So this game is geared towards children and yet requires you to throw money at it. In my opinion, I do not like this. I feel like it lures kids in and then requires a membership and microtransactions for them to enjoy it. Its like baking a cake in front of a kid and then letting them lick the icing off of the spatula and then telling them to ask their parents for money so they can have a slice. So I guess this game is fine if you don't mind throwing money at a buggy game for your kid.TL;DR very cute, very easy to play, very buggy, needs membership and microtransactions to be fully enjoyed

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												As a mom, I'm always looking for games that my daughter can play. This review is a mix of her opinion and mine.Graphics.Daughter - Pretty colors! I like being the pink elephant! Me - Very bright and fun graphics. No adjustable settings so quality is lacking.Gramplay.Daughter - "Mom, why are people standing on top of each other?" "Why is there nothing here?" "I don't like this game, can I play Minecraft instead?" Me - This is where the game quickly falls off. A lot of AFK'ers. I can assume that people with slower computers might actually start experiancing lag in certain areas. (Think Stormwind mailbox in WoW pre-BC). Huge areas have NOTHING. Just plain, open areas. Not even trees or flowers. Just green space. Sometimes you see water. Sometimes you see a random NPC. Either way, it's pretty dull and lackluster.I think they should have more mini games and maybe a few more educational elements?I see a lot of potinal in this title...but as of now, you don't have my daughters attention. Once again - very cute title, just need some TLC.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												I'll admit it, I love quirky, childish-looking MMOs. I always have. Be it Grand Fantasia from Aeria Games, or this particular MMO, something draws me to them. I played this game for two hours before writing this review. I love the art style, the bright colors, the whimsical nature of the game itself. I was a bit concerned with the fact that it is only F2P for the first 10 LEVELS, with any leveling past that requiring a subscription (monthly, 6-month, or yearly). I appreciate the fact that it is marketed toward children, because there aren't a lot of child-marketed MMOs for burgeoning gamers (like my neice). However, I think the game should be like many other F2P that include subscription services in that the features are only lightly restrictive, not to the point that you CANNOT LEVEL AT ALL past 10. I will say this - the voice acting was nice, the characters are quirky, and I enjoy the humor. It is also runs very well on my netbook. I like that it has elements reminiscent of Mabinogi or Villagers and Heroes (fishing, owning and decorating a home, a garden), but I'd love to see what else this game has to offer. I suppose I'll cough up the $3.99 for at least one month to see how it goes. All in all, despite the issue with the restrictions on F2P members, I really enjoyed what little I've played of this game and will likely continue. I'd give it a 7/10 at this time. Give it a shot, at least.

Cant say anything in chat since the email they send to enble chat links to a error page. So basicaly mute and stuck just because I dared to hand out books. And its not free to play since they lock you at lev 10 till you buy a membership. As it stands this game needs to work out all its bugs and make a effort to support its players better.

Posted: September 1, 2014
												Who cares what about what people who have played this game for ten minutes say. You can't just play a game for 0.2 hours and then confidently  declare it's a piece of crap. Go away. Bye.This game reminds me reminds me of Webkinz, also made by Ganz, and Toontown, a game by Disney recently shut down. I love both of those games and it was nice to see a combination of them. You pretty much just run around doing quests for various people around town. This game is meant for little children, so it does get a bit repetitive, but I still enjoyed it for the time I've played and I think I'll play a little more too. I would definitely recommend this to someone who likes MMO games made for younger audiences.

												My whole life Ive been in doubt. Until I found this... Immediatly when I saw it I fell in love and ordered posters and ritual chalk. Every night I would worship the gods of Amazing World by preforming rituals . These rituals would consist of me drawing circles with the chalk and dancing in a dress made of pictures of my character, poopnuggets. I ordered merchandise for my room. My addiction was getting bad. My mom called TLC. I was featured on episode 489 of my strange addiction. They couldn't stop my addiction. I ended up getting so obsessed that I created a portal to Amazing World. I now live there with my wife chickenmcnuggets, which was my other character when I played the game. I still preform rituals every night in my nice little house while I practice the art of Amazing World Ritual Magic, Volume 7. I collected it while fighting a giant green blob with 7 eyes. I will ALWAYS Love living here and WILL NEVER GO BACK YOU CAN'T MAKE ME!!!!!!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												As a mom, I'm always looking for games that my daughter can play. This review is a mix of her opinion and mine.Graphics.Daughter - Pretty colors! I like being the pink elephant! Me - Very bright and fun graphics. No adjustable settings so quality is lacking.Gramplay.Daughter - "Mom, why are people standing on top of each other?" "Why is there nothing here?" "I don't like this game, can I play Minecraft instead?" Me - This is where the game quickly falls off. A lot of AFK'ers. I can assume that people with slower computers might actually start experiancing lag in certain areas. (Think Stormwind mailbox in WoW pre-BC). Huge areas have NOTHING. Just plain, open areas. Not even trees or flowers. Just green space. Sometimes you see water. Sometimes you see a random NPC. Either way, it's pretty dull and lackluster.I think they should have more mini games and maybe a few more educational elements?I see a lot of potinal in this title...but as of now, you don't have my daughters attention. Once again - very cute title, just need some TLC.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												Real review is on last paragraph.In the world of AMAZINGWORLD! You only see a fun, childish, goofy world filled with joy and delight as you run around with your… hybrid…? Thing? By doing simple chores around Spring Bay, however… The truth is that there is more than just a joyous filled with terrible puns characters and fishes. Oh~ No! Once you dig deeper into the rabbit whole… You’ll know the real truth behind this so called “ERMIZIN’ VURD”, once you pay a price. To enter to the “Real World”, one must forfeit their very soul! (Or by spending some money) to enter to the TRUE WORLD! There is about 3 ways to enter, but it’s best to stick with the cheapest (Which is about a month) since you do NOT want to stay there any further (Or do you? I just don’t know really. I mean, leveling up is a joke). Once you pay up, you’re no up for the task for EVEN MOAR MISSIONS! Such has being inspired by DIRT! Or driving a killer car into some flowers or ice? Or whatever. You get to meet some new friends like Nibs the (who I think she has Daddy issue or just shy) Artist or even the great Princess Talia who (I believe is truly evil as she is trying to trap someone inside a globe) princess. Your goal in this world is to… I guess… Help the “Zings?/Talking animals with typical names that fits their type of occupation” in the community by doing chores and junk? (I mean, really, it’s just chores and gather stuff. This is some intense stuff btw). You get to fight many enemies! Such as a Nix! (Who has some anger issues with basically anything that isn’t moving. No joke, you’ll be seeing these guys just attacking some wall or the ground or… nothing at all.) There is also more enemies to fight against! Such as ANOTHER NIX, but with a HAT! OR WORSE!!! GLOVES, SCARF, AND SHOES!!! Now, I’m sure you want to know how to beat these devils of disasters and I’ll tell you how! YOU JUST!!! WALK RIGHT THROUGH THEM!!! I KNOW RIGHT?!?!?! How intense is that?! I mean, somehow, you are like immune to their dastardly deeds and by just walking right at them or by clicking them with your magical floating hand that follows you around! (P.S. You also have this magic hand that floats around you). Once you defeat a Nix, it’ll drop money! MONEY!!! (I love money! And free stuff!).As you travel around the world, helping Zings collect dirt and more dirt and a lot of dirt (You'll understand once you play further). You’ll be able to customize your Zing into BADA** OUTFITS!!! LIKE A GARDNER!!! OR A FISHERMAN!!! BUT IF YOU PAYED WITH YOUR VERY SOUL (Real money stuff/ Membership) YOU CAN GET EVEN BETTER GEAR!!! LIKE A CARDBOARD BOX!!! OR A PRINCESS SET OR a homeless zing… (No really! Just be creative with your choice). Now! Is there an end to this madness?! NO BECAUSE THERE IS NONE!!! You see, in this world, you can reach up to Level 50 (Members only) And you can collect stuff (Don’t expect much as a F2P)! And trade your stuff (Members only) And private chat with your fellow Adventurers as well (Members only)Oh yea, I forgot to mention that you can DANCE AND DO GESTURES AND JUMP!!! HOLY **** THAT’S SOME HIGH LEVEL MLG GAMING RIGHT THERE!!! Name me some games that can do that?! (Please don’t). As you continue your journey to do chores and repeated missions over and over again, you realize that there are “Spezul invents” such as PVE! These inventions (Events*) Take place around the world as your task is to join in with your fellow brethren (Sisters? I don’t know the gender of these things, they never really establish it). As you work together to defend the world against the Nixs’ and their hats and junk as you use your immunity to defeat them or let your magical hand do the clicking. Now that I have covered mostly everything there is to the world of gumball (Amazing World*) I guess… Oh wait…! I forgot that there is this Queen Vexas who is the Queen of the Nix who “I think she was trying to kill you at the beginning of the game” wanted to rule the world (Cliché’), but I think she just wanted love. So yea, just level up your Zing, get the best gear, Gamble on Karma’s Wheel of Misfortune, Survive the horrors of Outer Space with Cosmo, Search for Legendary Relics on Rune’s Secret Underground Universe, Escape from Howl’s HOWLRIBLE Circus attraction and fish for Steve. Alright, now the real review, the game is quite enjoyable… in about a week. Personally, if you really wanted to go through the game, I’d suggest getting the one month membership as the game isn’t that grand of a scale. You can easily reach to the max leveling easily without even trying, nearly everything drops to you as you play along the typical repeated missions, the game is so forgiving that everybody wins something, no matter what. There’s just not enough things to do around once you have gotten every achievement of doing something (E.x. Getting to level 50, Reach level 20 with this Npc, Steve) It’s just a silly game with nothing much to put forth, but hey, it’s a child’s game anyway, so don’t expect much out of it. Either than that, I did enjoyed it and I’d might give play it again, but for now, just not enough content to continue forth. 				  				7.4/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												Okay so I cut my teeth on family friendly MMOs and whilst the one I originally played has since closed down I keep my eye out for other ones.This is a subscription based MMO with a Cash Shop and a large amount of Free to Play content... well proportionally large anyway. It's aimed at quite small children. It's worth noting, I didn't pay up so my impressions are based entirely on the game as a free player.As a free player you have a level cap of 10. I reached this within the first half hour of playing. Your level limits your access to certain NPCs, their associated content and items within the "World Shop" a hybrid cash shop/game currency shop accessible from anywhere in the game. By level 10 you have access to about half the NPCs in the world.Each NPC then has a storyline that they want you to work through and a skill associated with whatever they do - although I'm not entirely sure "skill" is really the appropriate term. Once you have access to an NPC you can do their quests, complete their storyline and do random quests for them to gain further xp/sp/items/money. As your skill level raises you gain access to better items in their shop if they have one. You can max out any skill you can earn exp for even while you are F2P.Game play mostly consists of very simple mini games - really they start simple and then stay exactly that hard no matter how much you progress - that vary from small platforming areas, a small driving area or jigsaws and pairing puzzles, or interacting with things in the main game world... by running into them.There is essentially an endless amount of stuff to do as you have random quests assigned by the NPCs once you have completed their storyline. There is also fishing and treasure hunting which act slightly differently from the main NPC quests. There are open world events that occur pretty much constantly in the game world (and it must be noted that you can even earn small amounts of their cash based currency in these) and team games that are instanced - both requiring players to run into objects or monsters in a group effort to reach a target, where each individual is them rewarded based on how much they contributed to that target.Lastly in terms of customisation there is a large amount of clothing available but you will be stuck with the appearance (ears/fur colour etc) you initially choose for your character unless you cough up some cash and buy another (uncustomisable) avatar from the cash shop. This wouldn't be so bad apart from the fact that this amounts to the vast majority of the population in the game being one of three identical characters due to the massive lack of choice when creating a character. You do, however get a reasonably large estate with areas for housing and a garden available to decorate as well as your actual house, which is upgradable.From what I can see, if you paid up and got a membership you would gain access to more types of housing, the ability to level up and use content associated with higher levels (such as the other NPCs and items in the shop), some sort of super collections, and more multiplayer mini games. I think this game might appeal to small children for a few days, or maybe a week. There's no real depth and the difficulty doesn't scale at all, but it is cute and you do get a house and and funny bear/bunny/cow to dress up. I don't think it has any real longevity to it. It pulls the nasty trick of mixing in game currency and cash based currencies in the World Shop. The sub seems quite cheap but if the F2P portion of the game is anything to go for there is maybe two weeks worth of content there for a child, an adult could probably plough through it all in 3-4 days.I wouldn't recommend paying for it, or bothering with it if you're over the age of about 10. Whilst many family friendly games manage to have enough depth to be enjoyed by all ages... this one really doesn't. On the other hand if you're looking for something cute and friendly to entertain a small child for a few hours then this is right on target.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												Before anyone says anything did i play a game made for mental paitients and babies? Yeh i did, And did i like the game? Yes i did, And you know what it don't care. Sure this game wasn't World Of Warcraft brilliant but what do you expect from a childrens MMO game?For a kids game though the open world was kind of impressive, Like i said before not WOW open world but still not bad for a kids game. The graphics aren't to bad either and the open world looks pretty as an old man flying away on a frat boy with wings.  (Wich if you didn't realise is very beautiful). One thing that made me ammazed is that you can levelup, gain money, do main story quest, side quest and even upgrade your home!I was also supprised that this game ran smoothly, I didn't have a single bit of lag through out my hole play through. Anyway now on to the main part of any game the gameplay.The game controls like resident eveil on pc wich takes a while to get used to. Most of the game consits of gardening, running around and doing chores and possible a few home decorations along the way. And it was fairly enjoyable.I like this game and guess what should i care that i do? NO I SHOULDN'T I DON'T GIVE A SINGLE♥♥♥♥♥♥ DON'T YOU DARE SENSER ME STEAM!....Son of a ♥♥♥♥♥. Anyways now to my final result of this game. And i would give it a.7.5 out of ten.Yes for someone who isn't a little kid this game would be meh. But for a little kid its brilliant and thats the way i have to review it, Through the eyes of a little kid.Anyways im gonna go play with my crossdresser in this game see you later!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												Amazing World is a much different kind of mmo instead of fighting action packed you get cute funny little animals. It focuses on taking care of your very own garden and help the the town from being took over by the Queen Vexa. Now your more of just running up to the nix and scaring em off but theres a lot more to the game then all that. Theirs cute and fun minigames that seem to be different every time to from a mario like side scroller to riding a cute little car or even fixing puzzles.  The down side of it is once you hit level 10 you hit the end of the road for free to play. Now $4 a month seems reasonable to me for this funny little game but if you don't pay no more game for you! Its would be good for any age as long as they like cute.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
												First for the few parents that might actually want to let their kids play this game:Pro: chat has to be unblocked by a parent  or whoever the person is who's e-mail you used  when you complete certain Quests you can SEE the results of what you achieved no violence is used to dispel the Nix Kids can learn something when doing the QuestsCon: No full game-play possible without payment (Lvl Cap at lvl 10) repetitive questing tasks (Or is that a 'Pro' with/for kids?) You can jump off a bridge. A high bridge. In a kids-game.... without anything happening to your Zing. Your Zing is driving a car for some Quests. Let that sink in first. Your kid can drive that car in a game off-road and crash it against trees without consequences In relation to the point above: Your Zing isn't wearing a seat-belt while driving ^_^ YaySo you decided to play (or let your kid play) 'Amazing World'? Great. Here's one way it could go:After you created your Zing and dressed it... or not dressed it (not sure if that's good because 'animals' were not forced to wear clothes for 'humans' entertainment or bad, because little kids are given the opportunity to go bare) you land in Spring Bay (after a short time on the air-ship... and at your new home that you can't furnish yet) and get your first quests to help find your way around and earn your first exp. In some of these quests you have to collect something or solve a puzzle, or drive around in some kind of open car (without a seat-belt strapped on... really?!) and some other things.As you wander around you notice some other players running from one Nix invasion to the next, trying to dispel the most to get the extra prize- and you think "hey, why not try to win it myself?".You become ambitious and run around from one event to the next, too, only to realize how much time you are losing for the event by having to run to its location first.So you pick one location that you know the Nix invade regularly and lay in wait (now kids, remember that this should not be applied to school-ground games because it's not fair to the other kids and they might ban you from playing with them). When the Nix appear you can ambush them while they attack the Bay and dispel them- and win the prize of course.It's all about the prize!And you were there first, you have an advantage with your head-start and because of that no one will be able to beat you, your name is even announced as being in lead! 5 seconds left to the end of the event and BAM... someone else beat you to it.So you try again, and again, and AGAIN, but you still can't win. You slowly slip into depression and wonder "What's the point?".As you wander over a bridge to maybe do another Quest someone jumps over you and onto a railing to start fishing. You stop. Fishing? It might help you calm sown again. Yes, you could fish, too, but you want to do it someplace where no one could see you fail, you've had enough of other people besting you for the moment.You wander around looking for the perfect spot, but the ponds, the ocean and bridges are all occupied.You stop to think of any other place you could fish and maybe-... yes, you can jump on trees, why not on the high span of the big bridge? There isn't anyone else there and after much trial and error, falling down and jumping back up you finally reach the top.Ready to start you look for the button to start fishing- only to realize that you have not learned how to fish yet. That's just not fair!Seriously depressed now you jump down (...from the highest point of the bridge... as a 'kid'... seriously?!), just to land in the shallow waters.Unharmed.Without penalty.You don't even have a  scratch !What the heck?!You look for other ways to maybe kill your Zing: the Nix? Too easily scared away. drowning? ...Not a chance. in a Quest? Nope, no matter how bad you drive even that won't kill you; you drove against a tree and your car wasn't even damaged! maybe you can work your Zing to death... dehydrate him enough when he digs his own grave? No, worse yet, your effort doesn't even show! perhaps there are carnivorous fish somewhere in the ocean that would eat you if you catch them? You learn fishing but even after hours there is no fish willing to eat your pretty green-orange or pink-blue or whatever fluffy hide.You are slowly but surely becoming desperate and then another announcement- Queen Vexa is near!You try bargaining with her but she just ignores you. HOW. DARE. SHE!Now you're vexed and you. Will. END. HER!You are just about to start questing in earnest to get further along the story-line and defeat her with your amazing level and skills and NPC-friends, when you hit a figurative wall.You have reached Level 10. The level CAP for free players.There is just no way that you'd pay whatever amount of money once a month for a game that has ruined your Zing's life!You re-enter the world of rational thought and realize- you have already won!You are as leveled as you can become, no one can harm you; you are invincible, IMMORTAL even. You are a God and could progress even further if you wanted to, but why should you?Leave it to others to satisfy their inferiority complex by completing the menial task of defeating Queen Vexa (or cuddle her to death... whatever end is appropriate for a kids-game these days), because you- You Are  Done .

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 27, 2016
Product received for free
 Free Realms reincarnate Lots of quick mini-games (a Little Big Planet style platformer, plenty of collection missions (on foot or car), and other puzzles). Custom house. Lots of costumes. Different class based skills. Lots of teleporting. Clearly for a way younger audience, but hooked me for the time I spent to get to level 10. Also had to force myself to actually stop at 10, and not continue on untill my alarm for work goes off. You don't get to pick whatever name you want. You need to choose between 3 parts of a word to make your public name. So, naming yourself Asshat will only be seen by the asshat on his side of the keyboard.There's bouncing mushrooms on some roofs (little surprises for the explorers).

												This is a surprisingly good non-combat MMO. There is an in-depth housing system, public quests, group instances, collectible item sets, a full fishing system (complete with displayable fish), lots of minigames, and you can interact/play with a lot of the world and scenery. The Devs streamlined some features that other MMOs have to make it kid-friendly and have avoided a lot of problems that plague the genre. If you get a subscription the game gives a monthly gold allowance for the "real money" shop and the subscription price is peanuts (2.50 USD a month for a year or 3.99 USD for a single month) compared to other games that charge 14.99 USD. The Free-to-Play is more of a trial since you can't go past level 10.I really didn't expect to be writing such a positive review for this game, but there it is. It's really fun!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												It's hard for me to de-recommend this game, because it's not -bad-, I just think it is a bad idea.Amazing World is clearly aimed at children, and for what it is, I think it's excellent work, but is this really how anybody wants their child spending their time?It's a very happy, positive, friendly game with charming artwork and simple controls. Frankly, I think Ganz has done splendid work with this, in terms of design and production, but I just can't get over it being an MMO designed for CHILDREN. As in little children. I'm not against games being designed for children if they are educational, or in some way productive, but I didn't encounter anything I could describe as educational while I was in the game. In that way, I can't see any good cause for this game.The game encourages you to help others by rewarding you for doing various chores and solving puzzles. I guess you could say this is teaching good social behavior and work ethic, but real life is not like that at all. In reality, you spend a century or so working yourself to your grave and get nothing out of it. I am not a parent, though if I were, I would hardly stand for my child being (brainwashed?) made to think that doing good things means getting good rewards. Rather they should learn about the real world and be prepaired for what to expect from it. So in that way, I think this game is probably even harmful.I suppose there may be some small audience this game is just right for- if you have a small child that is handicapped in some way that prevents them from playing or studying and they need some nice way to pass their time between surgeries or treatments or just in general, then perhaps this could be a good escape for that child to do something entertaining that isn't full of distasteful nonsense like guns and explosions and zombies. Outside of that, I think any child is better off doing something that builds real skills like drawing or playing with building blocks.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
												Despite being a young man with little money to my name, I relatively enjoyed this game. However, this is more ideal for anyone 12 and under, who have access to their parents' credit card.Pros Hello Kitty-esque game art for lolis. (What can I say? I like pastels.) Cute character choices that make one squeal like a girl. (Guilty. Don't care.) Hilarious randomly generated names such as "Pompenstance". Somewhat cringey dialouge that's actually amusing. Adorable outfits and accessories for your character. (Wow. I felt really gay typing that.)Cons Plot holes that leave you confused and in the dust. (Like did I not help on ship? And who is Vexa?) Poor camera and movement controls. Dead end quests that you can't fulfill due to glitches. Poor mini game designs with wonky controls. Poor shop design accompanied by a somewhat confusing monetary system. Level capping that you end up reaching without difficulty. Forces you to pay membership if you wish to get past the level cap.As you can see, the cons end up out-weighing the pros. Play it if you wish. But keep in mind that if you don't want to pay for a membership, your time playing this game will be short lived.

This games name Amazing World is an understatement. It is the Best designed world i have ever seen in any mmorpg. The questing system is very solid and has so much variety. I really liked how i could place my own stuff at my house because... i like stuff. I find some players but they were in a dog only club. so i guess i cant be friend with them. content:
Posted: May 27, 2016
Product received for free
 Free Realms reincarnate Lots of quick mini-games (a Little Big Planet style platformer, plenty of collection missions (on foot or car), and other puzzles). Custom house. Lots of costumes. Different class based skills. Lots of teleporting. Clearly for a way younger audience, but hooked me for the time I spent to get to level 10. Also had to force myself to actually stop at 10, and not continue on untill my alarm for work goes off. You don't get to pick whatever name you want. You need to choose between 3 parts of a word to make your public name. So, naming yourself Asshat will only be seen by the asshat on his side of the keyboard.There's bouncing mushrooms on some roofs (little surprises for the explorers).
